web_research.query: How do Kaggle winners approach text classification problems with both text and meta features?
web_research.finding:
Based on winning solutions from several Kaggle NLP competitions, the most common workflow for text‑classification tasks that also have numerical or categorical “meta” features is:

1. **Clean the raw data and engineer simple meta features** – remove special characters, URLs, HTML tags and emojis; then create quantitative descriptors such as text length, proportion of uppercase characters, or any domain‑specific numeric/categorical fields. These engineered features often carry strong signal (e.g., upper‑case ratio was a key predictor in the Jigsaw toxicity competition) ([radurobu GitHub](https://github.com/radurobu/Jigsaw-Comments-Kaggle-Competition)).

web_research.query: What are the best approaches for handling class imbalance in binary classification on Kaggle?
web_research.finding:
Class imbalance is a common obstacle in Kaggle binary‑classification contests, especially when the target event (e.g., fraud, churn, or a rare disease) makes up only a few percent of the rows. The most reliable way to mitigate its effect is to combine **data‑level** and **algorithm‑level** tricks while evaluating with metrics that reward performance on the minority class.

At the data level, oversampling the rare class (random oversampling or synthetic methods such as SMOTE/ADASYN) or undersampling the majority class can give the model a more balanced training signal. The imbalanced‑learn library provides ready‑to‑use implementations of these techniques and integrates smoothly with scikit‑learn pipelines ([imbalanced‑learn.org](https://imbalanced-learn.org/stable/index.html)). web_research.query: What text preprocessing and feature engineering techniques work best for Reddit posts and social media text classification?
web_research.finding: Text preprocessing is the first‑line defence against the noise that makes Reddit and other social‑media posts difficult to model.  The most reliable pipeline starts by stripping out platform‑specific artefacts – URLs, subreddit tags (e.g., r/​news), user mentions (u/​name), markdown, HTML entities and non‑letter characters – and normalising case ([textPrep](https://www.churchill.io/papers/textprep.pdf)).  Next, a tokenizer that respects Reddit‑specific tokens (hashtags, emojis, emoticons) is applied; the open‑source RedditScore library even provides a “CrazyTokenizer” with built‑in options for these symbols ([RedditScore](https://redditscore.readthedocs.io/en/master)).  After tokenisation, most pipelines perform light linguistic normalisation: expanding contractions, removing or optionally keeping stop‑words, and applying lemmatisation or stemming (e.g., NLTK’s WordNet lemmatiser) to collapse inflectional forms. web_research.query: What ensembling strategies are most effective for Kaggle competitions combining text and tabular data?
web_research.finding: Ensembling is the single most reliable way to push a Kaggle solution past the “good‑enough” threshold when the data contain both free‑text fields and structured columns.  The current best practice is to train **heterogeneous base learners** – e.g. a transformer‑based text model (BERT, RoBERTa, or an LLM‑derived embedding) and several classical tabular algorithms such as LightGBM, CatBoost, or Random Forest – and then fuse their predictions with either **weighted averaging** or a **stacked meta‑learner**.  AutoGluon’s multimodal pipeline does exactly this: it fits a TextPredictor alongside a suite of tabular models and automatically combines them via a weighted ensemble or a stack ensemble, letting you tune the blend weights on a validation split ([auto.gluon.ai](https://auto.gluon.ai/0.1.0/tutorials/tabular_prediction/tabular-multimodal-text-others.html)).
